I recently purchased one of these phones.  It has been a cracking handset and I do not regret the cost at all.  It is expensive but the quality it brings to the table more than compensates for this.
 
It reminds me of a sandwich I once purchased from a more upmarket and reputable brasserie.  It was a gloriously lush and plentiful bounty with an abundance of Ham and lashings of other meats and salad.  My friend told me it would be a waste of money but, after he saw it in all its glory he instantly regretted his choice of artisan parsnip soup with crusty roll.  The soup WAS good, don't get me wrong, but the glory of my sandwich overshadowed the whole affair. 
My friend even goes so far as to say that it is the BIGGEST regret of his adult life and that he has ordered the sandwich multiple times since then and that it has never been made to the same glorious standards as the first time he laid his envious eyes upon it.  He has since fallen out with me as I never let him taste even the smallest bite of this magical creation.  i have received several threatening emails and lewd phone calls asking me to explain the feelings associated with eating the sandwich of sandwiches.  I can only decline to do this as re-living this visceral experience will probably drive me to very edge of my own sanity, even the brief memory of the enticing aroma is enough to push me close to the greatest moment of my life and, in that moment, i maybe tempted to end my thoughts there and slip into the bliss that was the perfectly seasoned mayonnaise dressed Excalibur Sandwich, a Sandwich fit for a king.
 
But I can't, because I still have 19 months payments left on my phone.
 
Oh yes, and my friend thinks the phone is alright, but he likes traditional headphones soooo...

"Apple claims the X has a 5.8" screen... except it's not what you may imagine this to be. The reason I stick with Apple year after year, even though they consistently fail to add or change features I would like and could have on an Android device, is stability. ThatÂ?s it. I need my phone to work, consistently, especially for the core functions of a communication device - email, text, Internet, messaging apps, etc.  I switched from Android with the iPhone 4 because it blew every existing Android device away in terms of speed and reliability in daily use.  Benchmarks are and were irrelevant to me; they donÂ?t console me when my phone freezes or reboots itself, when apps crash or fail to load or get sluggish, when messages mysteriously dissolve or fail to send.  These are problems I have never had on an iPhone. The Â?it just worksÂ? factor becomes really important when you rely on a device for critical communication for business. These days there are really impressive Android phones that seem to beat the iPhone out of the gate, even in actual speed tests and daily use case scenarios. But I know people who actually own those devices and I *still* see them stutter and fail at important tasks on occasion - something I literally never experience as an iOS user. Yes, bugs have creeped into iOS in recent iterations (which have generally been quickly squashed). But nothing which has caused slowdown or failure of essential tasks. And Android phones suffer from another frustrating problem IÂ?ve never experienced in iOS: slowdown over time. IÂ?ve never had to fully restore an iOS device to get it running without lag again. Ever. But that seems to be commonplace among Android devices. O donÂ?t have time in my life to be fiddling with my phone to get it running how I need it to work. Every cool and supposedly more convenient new feature that comes out on Android May seem like a reason to switch, but it always comes back to reliability for me. Over the course of my workday, I just need stuff to work how it should work when I want to use it, even if itÂ?s a fairly vanilla version of the thing. ThatÂ?s what keeps in in the iOS ecosystem.

And iphone x should be iphone 8Yes I agree as I already said, Apple and Samsung were two of the last companies to hold the physical home button when everyone else adopted on screen buttons, this year both companies decided to get rid of home buttons in their flagships and what we got to know about each one's approach.

A recent apps button and a 3d touch always on home button which wasn't seen in any phone till now, iPhone 7 had it but it wasn't embedded in the display itself. So a Samsung user coming from older models like S5, S6 or S7 will get almost the same experience. The fingerprint sensor was put to back this time but the phone can still be unlocked the same way, press the always on home button without waking up the phone while looking at the display and the phone will be unlocked in no time by the iris scanner giving an impression of inbuilt fingerprint sensor. The bottom navigation panel with back home and recent buttons can be hidden easily by two taps tho the home button will still be functioning on pressing the area where it's embedded giving the same experience of physical home button while watching videos, playing games and using any app. The overall experience was enhanced by options like swipe down anywhere on display for notification panel and swipe up anywhere for apps, these settings can be changed according to taste.

Its iPhone tenth anniversary time and Apple had to think diffferent to commemorate it. The iPhone X attempts to setup a change in the design language and UI gestures for the next few years.  Of course when you have a massive user base making big changes means bringing those users with you. Yes things will probably change a bit based on user feedback, this is a Gen 1 product, and yes the software will catch up with the hardware - Animoji is just a fun proof of concept to push developers to come up with their own ideas.
 
Having finally got one (thanks istocknow.com for the live stock pushes!) my initial thoughts are this. Screen is something else. Oled looks very good, but Ive noticed my iPad Pro screen looks better in any light than my 6S plus scree, and this seems to prove Truetone/HDR is key.
 
I admit I was a bit worried about losing Touch ID but amazingly FaceID seems to work at least as well as TouchID (shame you cant register two faces - I guess the bionic ML hardware isnt fast enough - A12 anyone - or the software isnt up to it yet?), and its quicker to setup.
 
Speed is well ... wow ... just like the iPad Pro 10.5. Cameras ... amazing for such a small device but no comparison to a DLSR (though those can be thousands with good lenses!). However, its a big improvement on the 6S plus and I thought that had a good camera. 
 
Is it worth the equivalent price of a 12 next week inch MacBook? Thats a personal decision but if you dont want to spend quite that much but want an iPhone, the iPhone 8 (and even 7) are mighty good phones with most of the functionality and very good LCD screens. But if you really really really want a X then consider the Apple Upgrade Programme. Its a way of paying monthly, its 0%, you get Applecare Plus, and you can upgrade to the Gen 2 product next year if you want or just continue paying it off.
Glad to hear in new feature of iPhone X specially in benchmark. but feeling bad to say the notch make it even worse than original iPhone.

Super AMOLED outdoes its predecessor and other technologies in the same generation by integrating the touch-sensor component to the screen rather than being installed separately above it. ThereÂ?s a growing trend in smartphone design that slices and dices the screen in shapes that stray further and further from the traditional rectangle. Rounded corners are a relatively tiny change and an old one at that (the Palm Pre had rounded corners). 
But then companies like LG, Essential and then Apple started cutting off larger portions. LG did it to fit a Â?secondary screenÂ? on the same line as the selfie camera, Essential just jammed the selfie camera in the top row of the screen and Apple was even more aggressive. 
And our readers want none of that Â? only a quarter of voters are okay with any sort of screen cutout. ItÂ?s a roughly even split between those who only accept small cutouts and those that will agree to a big chunk of their screen being taken away in the name of a great feature. 
Still, the overwhelming portion of the vote Â? 60% - went to the Rounded corners option. It is curious that the traditional rectangular screen got relatively weak support. We think this means that rounded corners are in as a design element.

Anticipation of the X is killing the sales of the 8. 
 
People whining about a new design every year should look at Apple's other products. Has the MacBook and iPad changed much in design the last 7-10 years? Yet, nobody complains about bezels on TVs and desktop displays. Only iPhones where people whine about new designs.
 
The rat race to get the X before the year ends and spend $200 more over the 8 Plus which essentially has same specs as the X is for people to chase this ego-driven feeling of having it before more people have it. But after awhile, X is as common as the 5s and 6 design. 
 
iPhone 8 = 4 & 6 remix
 
2017 is the first time in iPhone's history when it is considered a tick and tock update.
 
Tick - X  
Tock - 8 (6sss/7s)
 
I will still pick up the iPhone X but more likely when there are promos for it next year. I like the number 10 and letter X. Then I will pick up the 2020 iPhone because #13 is another lucky number for me. The one I will sometimes refer to as iPhone X3.
 
Please Apple, no more "s" naming schemes. Just keep it Roman numerical every year.
 
2017 - X 
2018 - XI 
2019 - XII 
2020 - XIII
 
Keep the naming simple even if the design is the same. X is able to reboot the naming for iPhones. Only the iPhone 4 was named properly for the generation it was released. The 4s, 5s, and 6s, ruined the generation order.
 
Being called iPhone XI (11) next year would also make it two numbers higher than the Galaxy S and Note line.

Every year around this time Apple releases its new iPhones and every year we get a few early reviews in just before the phone goes on sale. 
But this time, Apple has a more interesting phone coming out in November - the iPhone X - casting a shadow over the iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus - are they still worth it with a design dating back to 2014? Let's see what the reviewers say.
 
The consensus is that the Apple iPhone 8 and 8 Plus are let down by a tired design that's built on huge bezels and familiar aesthetics, but the new camera, wireless charging and chip partially make up for it. 
Engadget praises the iPhone 8 duo on the new excellent camera and a promising AR implementation but takes a point away for the design, despite the use of "grippier" glass. 
TheVerge makes mostly the same points - fast new processor, excellent camera and having wireless charging is nice. But Nilay Patel isn't too thrilled with the stiff design either. 
TechCrunch focuses on the new camera of the iPhone 8 Plus in their review hailing the new 12MP main camera as killer and the 8 Plus's Portrait Lighting as "working better than it has any right to". 
The same theme continues with The Telegraph - praise for the significantly improved camera and the new faster chipset. The new glass back gets a positive mention too. 
The New York Times review brands the new iPhones as the "ultimate refinement before eternal retirement". 
The Wall Street Journal (subscription required) is the only media that outright advises you avoid the iPhone 8 on the grounds that the 8 doesn't do enough to be considered more than a 7s, slightly better camera notwithstanding. 
John Gruber aka the Daring Fireball brands the iPhone 8 and 8 Plus "pretty good for a boring update". 
CNET would have you wait to see the iPhone X before deciding on buying either an iPhone 8 or 8 Plus. 
In its brief write-up USA Today describes the new glass and metal design as "lovely". 
Wired shares TechCrunch' sentiment that the new camera is kick-ass. It also hails the glass design as a big improvement coupled with wireless charging. 
Anyway we'll have even more to say when we get our hands on the new iPhones - camera samples, battery tests, loudspeaker test - all that jazz. So stay tuned!

The iPhone X did another quick run of Geekbench to solidify itself as the fastest smartphone around. 
Apple's upcoming flagship scored even more than it did last time and trounces all the top smartphones around. Granted benchmarks aren't great at making cross-platform comparisons, but the difference is still impressive. 
The A11 Bionic chipset has nearly doubled the single-core score of the A10 Fusion, which was already ahead of the Snapdragon 835 and Exynos 8895 Octa. Interestingly the A11 Bionic has the highest multi-core score, a first for an Apple chip. 
GeekBench 4 (multi-core)

Apple's A11 Bionic has a six-core processor with two high-powered cores and four power-efficient ones. But where it differs the most from its A10 Fusion predecessor is in its ability to run all six cores simultaneously - the A10 Fusion could only run one cluster at a time - either the fast or the efficient cores. 
The iPhone X also has 3GB of RAM - the same as the iPhone 7 Plus and 8 Plus and more than the 2GB iPhone 8 and iPhone 7 - more than enough for a smooth experience on iOS.

The iPhone X launch showed just how far Apple has to go with Facial Recognition. With Nougat 7.1 Iris Recognition security is bulletproof since your iris is impossible to duplicate. When Android's Oreo update is distributed in a few weeks iOS well fall even further behind, an outdated operating system which allows for ZERO CUSTOMIZATION. Apple only allows it's devices to do what Apple wants you to be able to do. Just another example of Apple's Proprietary Stranglehold all in the name of Corporate Profits! Android is also years ahead of Apple with both augmented and virtual reality -- it has Google Daydream for VR, Tango for AR, and recently announced a standalone headset. So go ahead Applehead's, drop an arm and leg for an already outdated device which will continue trying to catch with Open Source OS's.

Nags, 15 Sep 2017could you explain me what is Nural network????Hi! In this specific context is basically the computer programmed translation of a number of mathematical and statistical (complex) concepts.  
Let's try a simplification. Imagine to have a software that, whenever a red square is presented, it returns the word 'Red'. Then you change a little bit the input color so it is very close to the original red. And you program the software to write again 'Red'. Then you extend this 'learning' path of this computer software so that a number of degrees of differences of the original red is sill mapped to the output word 'Red'. At the end of this learning process your software will be able to 'recognize' an input color and decides if it has to return the 'Red' word as output or another string. Now, substitute the input color with the dots that map your face and the output string returned by the software with the lock/unlock mechanism of the new iPhone and here you are... 
In reality this a very complex topic but my small and poor example can help. :-)

Cpt. Power, 13 Sep 20174k or 2k HD or FHD is more than enough on so small screen nobody will see the differences. Human vision at this distance can see the difference (actually up to about 800ppi),
 
Also you have to bear in mind this is a pentile OLED display so the actual resolution is closer to 800p. With iPhone X preorders in 6 weeks and availability sometime after that, it leaves a large window for discussions about the pros and cons of this device. Apple is for the most part targeting current and past iPhone users. They're not likely to attract many crossover android users since most of the new features on this device have been components on android smartphones for some time now at a significantly lower price point. Facial Recognition, Wireless Charging, Imersive LED Display and Glass Body among others. A good portion of the early debate has revolved around cost. Even longtime iPhone devotees are going to think twice about the cost/value metric. Not only for the X flagship between $999.00 and $1,149.00 but even more so for the iPhone 8 and 8 Plus which are priced at $699.00 and $799.00 respectively. By the time you buy Earpods, Lighting Dock, Wireless Charger and a Case you'll have invested over $1,300.00 for the 64 GB and $1,450.00 for a 256 GB iPhone X and between $1,000.00 to $1,100.00 for the iPhone 8 and 8 Plus. Currently you can purchase a new iPhone 7 Plus in the mid $400.00 range. The new iPhone offerings are no doubt great devices but even hardcore applehead's will give flagship android devices a good look before they throw down that much cash on their next smartphone.

I am going to address the elephant in the room here, which is that iOS still can't drive high resolution displays efficiently from a battery standpoint. No 4K display (2160p), not even 1440p only 1125p???
 
With its massive display the iPhone X is one of the flagship phone with the smallest pixel density 458ppi vs. 537ppi for the LG V30 or 521ppi for the Note 8.
 
Based on this it is obvious to me that Apple don't take augmented reality seriously. How would Android fans turn to Apple when they persist in their avoidance of high resolution displays?
 
LG was able to fit a 3300mAh battery in a really thin device. Why can't Apple finally build a battery in that will allow them to have better autonomy at high resolutions and deliver a more comfortable augmented reality experience? 
 
It could have been a justified choice if they were going to make the phone a battery beast (what everyone is craving for the moment) but they haven't even provided the battery capacity yet, so don't even expect them to use the smaller display resolution to outperform Android in terms of autonomy. Lost opportunity in my opinion.
 
The Note 8 is too heavy and I don't like the elongated square design that much. 
The iPhone X doesn't join the high resolution display club and won't have the crazy batter size that people were hoping for. 
Neither have an emphasis on audio quality.
 
For me it will be either LG V30 or Axon 9. As much as I love the LG V30, I would prefer a dual stereo speaker setup but it will depend on ZTE'S ability to fit them in a bezelless design.
 
But at least those two brands put on emphasis on audio and microphone quality. What good is great camera if the recorded sound is not even remotely professional grade?

Funny how Android guys react to this phone and then calling apple fans out. I am an Android user for phone but IPad all the way for tablet for work and home. Had nearly every Android flagship in last 10 years. Only stayed away from Apple due to large screen to body ratio (and not only Apple to be fair - Sony and few others are on the list as well.)  
This time we have serious IPhone available and I am tempted for first time in years. Say what you want about IOS but it is still most stable and most supported system for phones/tablets. Maybe you don't use any pro apps but if you do you will find out that Android is poor at best - I work in music industry and what IOS achieved around music based apps is unbelievable. And this is possible due to stability and great IOS - no Android app is able to run steadily enough so it can be used for live music like we use on iPads - and that is a sign of great system. Sometimes is not about numbers but about reliability. I have LG G6 and Samsung S8 right now and both these things started to slow down and random moments and that is only about 3 months into use. Great phones - agree, but poor creative / professional tools.
